title: Snowflakes and Fairy Tales: Proportion, Imperfections and Symmetry in Barfield's Speaker's Meaning
description:
Video links and Book references follow notes.
Michael and I delve into Chapter 2 of Speaker's Meaning and discuss:

Why does it matter? Language as one of the most fundamental things.
Contraction and Expansion - the process of the evolution of language
(its relationship to art and science)
Material and Immaterial
Dogma - the protective resiliency to change so that it can survive long enough, stay continuous through time (built in redundancy)
Figurative language
Metaphor
finesse v geometry
When you personify something, you see more of what's going on.
(What does it want? What is It going to do?"
Patterns, symmetry, proportion, imperfections
Irreducible complexity when people are telling their own story, the marker of truth.
Snowflakes and Fairy Tales

Beyond Beauty: the Predictive Power of Symmetry
https://youtu.be/X6HobTJ2jnk
The Strangeness of the Good by James Matthew Wilson
https://www.amazon.com/Strangeness-Good-Including-Quarantine-Notebook/dp/1621386325/ref=sr_1_1?dchild=1&keywords=The+Strangeness+of+the+Good&qid=1630696093&s=books&sr=1-1
Noah Webster's American Dictionary of the English Language: (this one is expensive but this version has the best reviews for being the real thing and not just a part of it.)
https://www.amazon.com/American-Dictionary-English-Language-Facsimile/dp/091249803X/ref=sr_1_2?dchild=1&keywords=Noah+Webster%27s+1828+dictionary&qid=1630696443&s=books&sr=1-2
